review.title: Probabilistic Inductive Logic Programming Based on Answer Set Programming
review.abstract: We propose a new formal language for the expressive representation of probabilistic knowledge based on Answer Set Programming (ASP). It allows for the annotation of first-order formulas as well as ASP rules and facts with probabilities and for learning of such weights from data (parameter estimation). Weighted formulas are given a semantics in terms of soft and hard constraints which determine a probability distribution over answer sets. In contrast to related approaches, we approach inference by optionally utilizing so-called streamlining XOR constraints, in order to reduce the number of computed answer sets. Our approach is prototypically implemented. Examples illustrate the introduced concepts and point at issues and topics for future research.
histories: Appears in the Proceedings of the 15th International Workshop on Non-Monotonic Reasoning (NMR 2014)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in the Proceedings of the 15th International Workshop on Non-Monotonic Reasoning (NMR 2014)

sections.heading: 3 Probabilistic Answer Set Programming with PrASP
sections.text: Before turning to probabilistic reasoning and parameter estimation, we introduce our new language for probabilistic non-monotonic logic programming, called Probabilistic Answer Set Programming (PrASP). Syntax: Just add probabilities To remove unnecessary syntax constraints, and because we later need certain syntactical modifications of certain programs that can be more easily expressed in FirstOrder Logic (FOL), we allow FOL statements in our logical programs that use the F2LP conversion tool (Lee and Palla 2009). Specifically, a PrASP program consists of down-to-earth or non-down-down-down formulas annotated in full syntax with numerical annotations (provided by some domain experts or learned from data).If the weights are removed directly and limited variable domains are provided, any such program can be converted into an equivalent program.

sections.heading: An alternative approach: conversion into an equivalent non-probabilistic answer set program
sections.text: An alternative approach to a probable conclusion without calculation µ and without counting the weighted possible worlds ("much") would be to find an uncommented first-order coin program that reflects the desired probable nondeterminism (choice) of a given formula 1 program. To make this idea more intuitive, we imagine that every possible world corresponds to a room. Instead of encountering a certain room with a certain frequency, we create more rooms, all of which have the same views, size, and furniture from the observer's point of view. The number of these rooms reflects the probability of this type of room.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: With this introductory talk, we presented a novel framework for arguing with uncertainties and parameter estimates based on Answer Set Programming, with support for probabilistically weighted formulas in background knowledge, hypotheses, and queries. While our current framework certainly leaves room for future improvement, we believe we have already identified a new path toward more viable, likely inductive response set programming with a high degree of meaningfulness. Ongoing work focuses on performance improvements, theoretical analysis (especially in terms of minimal sample count and inference accuracy), empirical evaluation, and exploration of viable approaches to PrASP structural learning.

In contrast to related approaches, we approach inference by optionally utilizing so-called streamlining XOR constraints, in order to reduce the number of computed answer sets.
